Award.AwardTitle: A Test-bed for Analyzing the Security and Resilience of the DG-Integrated Electric Power Distribution Network

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the proposed research is to develop a simulation test-bed to analyze the security and resilience of the microgrid under diverse operating conditions. This test-bed will allow a detailed performance evaluation of different types and sizes of distributed generation and storage units, together with various generation and load control mechanisms. This research applies concepts from the fields of power systems, agent-based technologies, IP-based network and game theory to address the modeling and simulation of an intelligent microgrid at the distribution level.

Intellectual merit: The intellectual merit of this research is the development of a simulation test bed that comprises detailed device models and multi-agent technologies for microgrid operation. The test bed is expected to assist with the analysis and evaluation of electric power microgrid designs. It will assist researchers, system planners, and policy makers in quantifying and analyzing the impact of various distributed generation devices, as well as various load and generation control algorithms, on the security and resiliency of the electric power microgrid.

Broader impacts: The microgrid simulation test bed is expected to broaden the student experience beyond the academic environment through real-world examples and case studies. In addition, it will provide a platform for collaborative research opportunities with colleagues in academia and industry who are active in similar research areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary: The objective of this research was to develop a test bed for an electric power distribution network simulation that comprises various device models – including both distributed energy sources and controllable loads, as well as a multi-agent system that can provide intelligent, distributed and autonomous control features. The proposed test bed revolves around the concept of a specialized microgrid called an “Intelligent Distributed Autonomous Power Systems” (IDAPS). IDAPS represents a specialized microgrid that can coordinate energy sources and loads in an efficient manner. During the course of the project, a diverse set of device models – both supply-side and demand-side – were developed, together with their agent-based control algorithms. In particular, these include:

  • The development of supply-side device models, including solar photovoltaics (PV), wind turbines, microturbines, fuel cells and battery energy storage;
  • The development of power-intensive controllable residential load models, including air conditioners, electric water heaters, clothes dryers and electric vehicles;
  • The development of an agent-based decision-making tool for electric power distribution operation, including agent architectures, agent algorithms, agent negotiation process, agent facts, ontology and knowledge creation.

All supply-side and demand-side components, together with their control model, were integrated together to achieve the proposed test bed that can be used to evaluate the impact of various control algorithms on a particular device or at a system level, thus allowing qualification and analysis of distribution network operation at various levels of a distribution system: home, distribution transformer and distribution feeder. The usefulness of the developed device models, agent-based control algorithms and the overall test bed was demonstrated through selected case studies.

The technical merit: This research applied the knowledge of power systems, agent?based technologies, IP-based network and optimization theory toward the development of the test bed for an electric power distribution network simulation. Through the introduction of the simulation test bed that allows integration of distributed control, advanced communications, distributed generation and demand management components, this work is expected to contribute to improve current planning and decision?making practices for electric power distribution networks. Therefore, the distribution network can be designed to be more distributed, resilient and efficient. Major research contributions are pertaining to (a) the modification/development of existing distributed energy sources and load models; (b) the development of an agent framework to coordinate the interaction among various DG devices and loads, thus enabling a more efficient and resilient distribution network operation; (c) the development of agent?based algorithms for demand management to enable energy security improvement during normal operation and increase resiliency during emergency conditions.

 

Broader impact: The test bed is intended for use by researchers and utility engineers to analyze the implication of applying different control algorithms, particularly those relevant to demand response and device-level control, on a distribution network operation. Technical research outcomes – which are agent?based framework and algorithms – can be perceived as building blocks toward building a more resilient electric power distribution system that allows coordination among various types of DGs and controllable loads, including electric vehicles.
